metadata.document_name: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar
metadata.source_pdf: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
defendants: RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE
respondents: RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE
key_issues: The petitioners are seeking removal of the impugned trademark "CLARIWASH" from the Register of Trademarks due to prior use and registration of similar trademarks by the petitioners.
The respondent's trademark application was filed on 16th April, 2010, but the earliest invoice filed on behalf of the respondents is of 10th May, 2010, which may affect their claim of prior use.

The petitioner is claiming prior user of the "Clari" formative marks from the year 2009, which was acquired from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals in 2013 through a Deed of Assignment and Asset Transfer Agreement.
The respondent's registration of the trademark "CLARIWASH" may be invalid due to a mistake in the Examination Report, which noted the mark as "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH".

The petitioner is arguing that the respondent cannot claim the benefit of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act, as there was no use by the respondent at the time of the trademark application.
The petitioner's registration of the trademark "CLARI-FI" on 3rd February, 2010, with user from 1st April, 2009, may take priority over the respondent's registration of "CLARIWASH".

The transfer of reputation and goodwill related to the "Clari" formative marks from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals to the petitioner through the Deed of Assignment and Asset Transfer Agreement is a crucial factor in determining prior use and ownership.
The respondent's modification of the Registration Certificate from "CHARIWASH" to "CLARIWASH" may be a procedural issue that affects the validity of their trademark registration.

The court must consider the principles of trademark law, including prior use, registration, and goodwill, to determine the validity of the respondent's trademark registration and the petitioner's claim for removal.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. vs. Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care and Anr.**

**Background:**

The case involves a trademark cancellation petition filed by L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. (the petitioner) against Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care (the respondent) before the High Court of Delhi. The petitioner sought to cancel the respondent's registered trademark "CLARIWASH" (Registration No. 1950938) in Class 03, which was allegedly infringing on the petitioner's prior usership and goodwill of the "Clari" formative marks.

**Legal Issues:**

1. **Prior Usership and Goodwill**: The petitioner claimed prior usership and goodwill of the "Clari" formative marks, which were allegedly infringed by the respondent's "CLARIWASH" mark.
2. **Concurrent User**: The respondent's claim of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act, 1999, was disputed by the petitioner, who argued that there was no use by the respondent at the time of the trademark application.
3. **Error in Registration Certificate**: The petitioner alleged that the Registry had erroneously modified the Certificate of Registration from "CHARIWASH" to "CLARIWASH" without following the correct procedure.

**Arguments:**

The petitioner argued that:

1. The respondent's "CLARIWASH" mark was similar to the petitioner's prior "Clari" formative marks, which would cause confusion among consumers.
2. The respondent had no prior user or goodwill in the "CLARIWASH" mark, as the first invoice filed on behalf of the respondent was dated May 10, 2010, after the registration of the petitioner's "Clari" formative marks.
3. The error in the Registration Certificate was a procedural irregularity that rendered the respondent's registration invalid.

The respondent argued that:

1. The petitioner's "Clari" formative marks were not identical to the respondent's "CLARIWASH" mark, and therefore, did not infringe on the petitioner's rights.
2. The respondent had filed a suit for infringement against the petitioner, which was pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari.

**Court Findings:**

The court considered the petitioner's arguments and evidence, including the fact that the respondent's first invoice was dated after the registration of the petitioner's "Clari" formative marks. The court also examined the error in the Registration Certificate and the respondent's claim of concurrent user.

**Decision:**

The High Court of Delhi, in its judgment delivered on March 23, 2023, allowed the petitioner's cancellation petition and directed the removal of the respondent's registered trademark "CLARIWASH" from the Register of Trademarks. The court held that the respondent had no prior user or goodwill in the "CLARIWASH" mark and that the error in the Registration Certificate was a procedural irregularity that rendered the respondent's registration invalid.

The court's decision was based on the petitioner's prior usership and goodwill of the "Clari" formative marks, as well as the lack of evidence of the respondent's prior use of the "CLARIWASH" mark. The court's ruling highlights the importance of prior usership and goodwill in trademark law, as well as the need for procedural regularity in the registration of trademarks.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 1 of 10 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
Judgment Reserved on:  27th February, 2023  
Judgment Delivered on: 23rd March, 2023  
 
+  
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
 
LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD.  
 
       
  ..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Mr. 
S.K. 
Bansal 
and 
Mr.Ajay 
Amitabh Suman, Advocates 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING  
AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE AND ANR 
...... Respondents 
Through: 
Mr. Pramod Kumar Singh and 
Ms. Priya Nagpal, Advocates for R-1. 
 
Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, 
CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, 
Mr. 
Sagar 
Mehlawat 
and 
Mr.Alexander 
Mathai 
Paikaday, 
Advocates for R-2. 
 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
JUDGMENT 
1. 
The present cancellation petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner seeking removal of impugned trademark „CLARIWASH‟ 
registered under No.1950938 in Class 03 in the name of the respondent no.1 
from the Register of Trademarks. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 2 of 10 
 
CASE SET UP BY THE PETITIONER 
2. 
The case set up in the petition is as under: 
2.1. The petitioner is the registered proprietor of various trademarks with 
the word “Clari”, details of which are given in paragraph 4 of the 
petition. The petitioner is engaged in the business of manufacture and 
sale of a wide range of hair care, skin care, toiletries and beauty 
products.  
2.2. The “CLARIWASH” mark was adopted in 2010 by the petitioner and 
has been used along with the other “Clari” formative marks. 
2.3. The first of the “Clari” formative marks were adopted by a company 
by the name of Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd. [hereinafter 
“Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals”] in 2009. The petitioner acquired Cheryl‟s 
Cosmeceuticals in 2013 by way of a Deed of Assignment and Asset 
Transfer Agreement.  
2.4. By virtue of the said Deed of Assignment and Transfer Agreement, 
the reputation and goodwill related to various “Clari” formative marks 
stood transferred to the petitioner. 
2.5. The petitioner is the prior user of the “Clari” formative marks from 
the year 2009 on account of the user of his predecessor. 
2.6. The respondent no.1 applied for registration of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH” in Class 03 on 16th April, 2010 showing user from 
16th November, 2009. However, the first invoice filed on behalf of the 
respondent no.1 is dated 10th May, 2010, which is after the 
registration of the “Clari” formative marks. On the other hand, the 
registration granted in favour of the petitioner in respect of trademark 
“CLARI-FI” is of 3rd February, 2010 with user from 1st April, 2009. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 3 of 10 
 
2.7. It is further submitted that the respondent no.1 cannot claim the 
benefit of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act as 
there was no use by the respondent no.1 at the time of the trademark 
application. The trademark application was filed on 16th April, 2010 
and the earliest invoice filed on behalf of the respondents is of 10th 
May, 2010. 
2.8. The Examination Report dated 3rd January, 2012 issued by the 
Registrar of Trade Marks wrongly notes the mark of the respondent 
no.1 as “CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Based on the 
aforesaid Examination Report, the Certificate of Registration of Trade 
Mark was issued in favour of the respondent no.1 for the word mark 
“CHARIWASH”. However, subsequently, the Certificate was 
modified by the Registry to “CLARIWASH”. 
2.9. The procedure adopted by the Registry in changing the Registration 
Certificate of word mark from “CHARIWASH” to “CLARIWASH” 
was an erroneous. Having discovered the error, the Registry should 
have 
proceeded 
for 
a 
fresh 
examination 
for 
the 
mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance in this regard is placed on the orders of the 
Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Vans Inc. USA v. 
Fateh Chand Bhansali and Anr., 2020 SCC OnLine IPAB 44 and 
Prajapati Constructions Ltd. v.  Manoj Ramanand Prajapati and 
Anr., 2018 SCC OnLine IPAB 313. 
CASE SET UP BY THE RESPONDENT 
3. 
The case set up by the respondent no.1 is as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 4 of 10 
 
3.1. The respondent no.1 has filed a suit for infringement of the registered 
trademark “CLARIWASH” of the respondent no.1 against the 
petitioner, which is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari. 
3.2. Even though the Examination Report was in respect of the mark 
“CHARIWASH”, the Trademark Journal correctly published the 
mark “CLARIWASH” and not “CHARIWASH”. In May, 2012, the 
Trademark Registry erroneously issued Trademark Registration 
Certificate for the word mark “CHARIWASH”. The respondent no.1 
immediately filed an application to rectify the said clerical error and 
accordingly, the Trademark Registry rectified the error and issued a 
fresh Trademark Registration Certificate for the correct word mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance is placed on the judgment of a Coordinate 
Bench in Epsilon Publishing House Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India and 
Ors., 2009 SCC OnLine Del 3922.  
3.3. Though the petitioner claims adoption of the mark “CLARIWASH” 
in the year 2010, nothing has been filed in support of the same. 
Further, the petitioner has not filed any application for registration of 
the mark “CLARIWASH” till date. 
3.4. Use of the mark “CLARIWASH” by the petitioner or its predecessor 
was only in the year 2013. Attention of the Court in this regard is 
drawn to the invoices filed on behalf petitioner. 
3.5. The petitioner uses several other marks other than the “Clari” 
formative marks. Therefore, it cannot be said that “Clari” belongs to a 
family of marks. 
3.6. The petitioner cannot claim any monopoly on a part of the trademark 
“Clari”. The fact that the petitioner has various marks registered with 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 5 of 10 
 
the prefix “Clari” does not mean that the registration granted in favour 
of the respondent no.1 for the mark “CLARIWASH” is defective. 
There are a number of trademarks registered where the word “Clari” 
has been used as a prefix or suffix.  
3.7. The petitioner was aware of the respondent‟s use of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH”, yet never applied for its trademark registration. 
4. 
Despite opportunity being granted, the respondent no.2 has not filed 
any reply/counter statement or written submissions in the present petition. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
5. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
6. 
In the present case, it appears from the record that the Trademarks 
Registry erroneously issued the Examination Report for the mark 
“CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Yet again, the Registry issued 
a Trademark Registration Certificate in favour of the respondent, wherein 
the mark of the respondent was wrongly shown as “CHARIWASH”. 
Immediately thereafter, an application was filed on behalf of the respondents 
on 14th June, 2012, requesting for rectification of the clerical error and the 
same was allowed by the Registry and a correct Trademark Registration 
Certificate was issued in favour of the respondent for the mark 
“CLARIWASH”. However, it is pertinent to note that the mark of the 
respondent no.1 was published correctly as “CLARIWASH” in the 
Trademark Journal No.1519 on 16th January, 2012.  Therefore, it was open 
for the petitioner or its predecessor to oppose the said application, which 
they failed to do. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 6 of 10 
 
7. 
If the Registrar has committed an error and issued a faulty 
examination report, the respondent no.1 cannot be faulted for the same.  It is 
not that the respondent no.1 had misrepresented or misled the trademark 
Registry into issuing a faulty examination report.  The registration of a 
trademark entails valuable rights and the respondent no.1 cannot be deprived 
of the same on account of mistake committed by the Registry. Therefore, 
this by itself cannot be the ground for removal of the registration granted in 
favour of the respondent no.1. 
8. 
In Epsilon Publishing (supra), a Coordinate Bench of this Court was 
seized of a petition challenging the order of the Registrar renewing the 
trademark granted in favour of the respondent therein.  The ground taken by 
the petitioner was that since the respondent had not filed an application for 
renewal of the registration before its expiration and not paid the surcharge, 
the Registrar was required to remove the trademark from the Register.  
While noting that the Trade Marks Registry has not adhered to the statutory 
timelines, it was held that the respondent cannot be penalized for the same 
and would be entitled to pursue its renewal application.  In the said case, the 
Registrar had admitted that the renewal application filed on behalf of the 
private respondent was not examined and therefore, could not be processed 
further.  It was observed that the private respondent could not be deprived of 
its rights on account of the fault of the Registrar. The relevant observations 
of the court as set out in paragraph 26 are reproduced below: 
“26. 
There may be merit in the contention that the Registrar 
has to follow the procedure as prescribed; however, the essential 
question is not whether the Registrar has any discretion in the 
matter, but, what are the consequences of the Registrar not 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 7 of 10 
 
following the established procedure? Plainly, in the facts of the 
present case, it is apparent that the Trademark Registry has not 
adhered to the timelines as required. Surely, respondent no.3 
cannot be penalised for the same and would be entitled to purse its 
application for renewal of its trademark. The same was filed well 
within the period of six months and even though the same was not 
accompanied by a fee of surcharge, nonetheless, respondent no.3 
had the right to know the fate of its application. Since no 
deficiency was pointed out at the material time, respondent no.3 
cannot be deprived of its valuable rights to cure the defects within 
the prescribed period. The Registrar also did not advertise the 
removal of the trademark as required under section 25(4) of the 
Act read with Rule 66 of the 2002 Rules. Such advertisement 
would have provided another opportunity for the petitioner to seek 
restoration of the trademark.” 
9. 
The dicta of the aforesaid judgment is squarely applicable to the 
present case. The respondent no.1 cannot be deprived of his valuable rights 
of registration on account of the error of the Registry. 
10. 
Counsel for the petitioner has relied upon the orders passed by the 
IPAB in Prajapati Constructions (supra) and Vans Inc. USA (supra) in 
support of his submission that the Registrar of Trade Marks has to follow 
the statutory procedure prescribed under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 in 
respect of examination of a trade mark application. At the outset, it may be 
noted that both are interim orders passed by the IPAB and therefore, no 
reliance can be placed on the same in the present case, which is at the stage 
of final hearing. After noticing the various procedural lapses committed by 
the Trademark Registry, the IPAB only ordered that the respondent therein 
shall not rely upon the impugned registration in any proceedings during the 
pendency of the rectification proceedings.  There was no order for removal 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 8 of 10 
 
of the registration granted in favour of the respondent on account of lapses 
committed by the Registry.  
11. 
Reliance has also been placed on the order passed by the IPAB in 
Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain (Proporietor) & 
Anr., 2018 (76) PTC 479 [IPAB]. In the aforesaid order, the marks of the 
petitioner and the respondent were identical, namely, “HOWRAH BIDI”. 
The respondent therein had merely added a number to the mark “HOWRAH 
BIDI”, which is not the position in the present case. Therefore, the said 
judgment does not further the case of the petitioner. 
12. 
Counsel for the petitioner also submitted that the matter be remanded 
back to the Registry for reconsideration of the trademark application of the 
respondent no.1 from the stage of issuance of examination report. I am not 
inclined to remand back the matter as this would amount to cancellation of 
the registration already granted in favour of the respondent no.1 as far back 
as in 2012. Therefore, I proceed to consider the matter on merits, i.e., 
whether the registration in favour of the respondent no.1 was granted 
erroneously. 
13. 
At the time when the respondent no.1 filed its application for 
registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” in 2010, there was one mark of the 
predecessor of the petitioner, “CLARI-FI”, that was registered in Class 03. 
All other marks of the petitioner with the term “Clari” have been registered 
subsequent to the registration of the respondent no.1. The petitioner acquired 
rights in the mark “CLARI-FI” in 2013, pursuant to the Asset Transfer 
Agreement dated 19th September, 2013. It is submitted on behalf of the 
petitioner that since the mark of the respondent no.1, “CLARIWASH” was 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 9 of 10 
 
similar to the earlier registered trademark “CLARI-FI”, in respect of similar 
goods, the respondent no.1 should not have been granted registration in 
terms of Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. In my considered view, 
there is no similarity in the marks “CLARI-FI” and “CLARIWASH” so as 
to cause a likelihood of confusion in the public or likelihood of association 
of “CLARIWASH” with “CLARI-FI”. It is a settled position of law that 
while comparing the marks, the marks have to be seen as a whole and 
cannot be broken into their individual components. Reference in this regard 
may be made to the judgment of the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd., AIR 1960 SC 142. 
Therefore, “CLARIWASH” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “WASH” and 
similarly, “CLARI-FI” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “FI”. Taken as a 
whole, there is no similarity in the competing marks so as to cause 
confusion.  Therefore, on the basis of registration of the mark “CLARI-FI”, 
the petitioner cannot seek cancellation of the trademark “CLARIWASH” 
registered in favour of the respondent no.1 in Class 03.  
14. 
Under the Asset Transfer Agreement dated 19th September, 2013, the 
petitioner took over approximately 170 marks, both registered and pending 
registration, from Cheryl‟s Consmeceuticals. Only 12 out of the 170 marks 
use “Clari” as a part of the mark. Therefore, the petitioner cannot say that 
there was a family of marks with the term “Clari” as part of the marks that 
were registered in favour of the petitioner. 
15. 
Counsel for the petitioner has contended that even though the user 
shown in the application filed by the respondent no.1 is 16th November, 
2009, the first invoice placed on record is of 12th May, 2010. In my view, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 10 of 10 
 
this would not make any difference as registration can be granted on a 
„proposed to be used‟ basis. Even if the first user of the respondent no.1 is 
taken to be 12th May, 2010, the user of the petitioner or its predecessor of 
the trademark “CLARIWASH” is after the said date. Nothing has been 
placed on record on behalf of the petitioner to show that the mark 
“CLARIWASH” was adopted in 2010 either by the petitioner or its 
predecessor. It was only on 22nd August, 2013 that a license was issued by 
the FDA, Maharashtra in favour of the predecessor of the petitioner, 
Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals. Even the first invoice placed on record by the 
petitioner that corresponds to the use of “CLARIWASH” is dated 5th 
December, 2013 and the sales figures in the petition have been given only 
from the year 2014. It is also relevant to note that the petitioner has not filed 
any application for registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” till date.   
16. 
In light of the discussion above, no grounds for rectification are made 
out.   
17. 
The petition is dismissed with no order as to costs. 
 
 
                       AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 23, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the legal proceedings involve a cancellation petition filed by L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd. (the petitioner) against Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care and another (the respondents). The petition seeks to remove the trademark "CLARIWASH" (registered under No.1950938 in Class 03) from the Register of Trademarks.

The petitioner claims to be the prior user of the "Clari" formative marks, having acquired the reputation and goodwill related to these marks from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd. in 2013. The petitioner argues that the respondent's registration of the "CLARIWASH" mark in 2010 is invalid, as the first invoice filed by the respondent is dated May 10, 2010, which is after the registration of the petitioner's "Clari" formative marks.

The key dates mentioned in the document are:

* February 27, 2023: Judgment reserved
* March 23, 2023: Judgment delivered
* April 16, 2010: Respondent applied for registration of the "CLARIWASH" mark
* November 16, 2009: Respondent claimed user of the "CLARIWASH" mark
* February 3, 2010: Petitioner's registration of the "CLARI-FI" mark with user from April 1, 2009

The parties involved are represented by various advocates, including Mr. S.K. Bansal and Mr. Ajay Amitabh Suman for the petitioner, and Mr. Pramod Kumar Singh and Ms. Priya Nagpal for the respondent. The case was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf)

The petition was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal. Judgment was reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. The petitioner was represented by Mr. S.K. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", page 1)

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary: According to page 2 of the PDF "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf" (2023:DHC:2089), the petitioner, L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd., is the registered proprietor of various trademarks with the word "Clari". The petitioner acquired Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals, which adopted the "Clari" marks in 2009, through a Deed of Assignment and Asset Transfer Agreement in 2013. The petitioner claims to be the prior user of the "Clari" marks from 2009. The respondent, Rajesh Kumar Taneja, applied for registration of the trademark "CLARIWASH" on April 16, 2010, but the first invoice was dated May 10, 2010, after the petitioner's registration of "CLARI-FI" on February 3, 2010, with user from April 1, 2009. The case was heard in the High Court of Delhi, with judgment reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, page 2)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 2 of 10 
 
CASE SET UP BY THE PETITIONER 
2. 
The case set up in the petition is as under: 
2.1. The petitioner is the registered proprietor of various trademarks with 
the word “Clari”, details of which are given in paragraph 4 of the 
petition. The petitioner is engaged in the business of manufacture and 
sale of a wide range of hair care, skin care, toiletries and beauty 
products.  
2.2. The “CLARIWASH” mark was adopted in 2010 by the petitioner and 
has been used along with the other “Clari” formative marks. 
2.3. The first of the “Clari” formative marks were adopted by a company 
by the name of Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd. [hereinafter 
“Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals”] in 2009. The petitioner acquired Cheryl‟s 
Cosmeceuticals in 2013 by way of a Deed of Assignment and Asset 
Transfer Agreement.  
2.4. By virtue of the said Deed of Assignment and Transfer Agreement, 
the reputation and goodwill related to various “Clari” formative marks 
stood transferred to the petitioner. 
2.5. The petitioner is the prior user of the “Clari” formative marks from 
the year 2009 on account of the user of his predecessor. 
2.6. The respondent no.1 applied for registration of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH” in Class 03 on 16th April, 2010 showing user from 
16th November, 2009. However, the first invoice filed on behalf of the 
respondent no.1 is dated 10th May, 2010, which is after the 
registration of the “Clari” formative marks. On the other hand, the 
registration granted in favour of the petitioner in respect of trademark 
“CLARI-FI” is of 3rd February, 2010 with user from 1st April, 2009. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", a legal proceeding (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022) was held in the High Court of Delhi. The petitioner, L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd., filed a case against Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care. The judgment was reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023.

The petitioner argued that the respondent's trademark registration for "CLARIWASH" was erroneous due to a clerical mistake, as the Examination Report mentioned "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH". The respondent countered that the Trademark Journal correctly published the mark "CLARIWASH" and that the error was rectified by the Trademark Registry.

The respondent also stated that they had filed a suit for infringement of their registered trademark "CLARIWASH" against the petitioner, which is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari. The petitioner claimed adoption of the mark "CLARIWASH" in 2010, but the respondent argued that there was no evidence to support this claim and that the petitioner's use of the mark was only in 2013.

The document highlights the arguments and counter-arguments of both parties, with the petitioner seeking to challenge the respondent's trademark registration and the respondent seeking to defend their registration. The case revolves around the legal proceedings, facts, and arguments presented by both parties, as detailed in the PDF document (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, 2023:DHC:2089).
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the petitioner argues that the respondent cannot claim concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act. The trademark application was filed on April 16, 2010, and the respondent's earliest invoice is dated May 10, 2010. The Examination Report dated January 3, 2012, incorrectly noted the respondent's mark as "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH", leading to an erroneous registration certificate. The petitioner cites IPAB orders in Vans Inc. USA v. Fateh Chand Bhansali and Prajapati Constructions Ltd. v. Manoj Ramanand Prajapati to support their argument that the Registry should have proceeded with a fresh examination for the mark "CLARIWASH". The case is C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022, with judgment reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 3 of 10 
 
2.7. It is further submitted that the respondent no.1 cannot claim the 
benefit of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act as 
there was no use by the respondent no.1 at the time of the trademark 
application. The trademark application was filed on 16th April, 2010 
and the earliest invoice filed on behalf of the respondents is of 10th 
May, 2010. 
2.8. The Examination Report dated 3rd January, 2012 issued by the 
Registrar of Trade Marks wrongly notes the mark of the respondent 
no.1 as “CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Based on the 
aforesaid Examination Report, the Certificate of Registration of Trade 
Mark was issued in favour of the respondent no.1 for the word mark 
“CHARIWASH”. However, subsequently, the Certificate was 
modified by the Registry to “CLARIWASH”. 
2.9. The procedure adopted by the Registry in changing the Registration 
Certificate of word mark from “CHARIWASH” to “CLARIWASH” 
was an erroneous. Having discovered the error, the Registry should 
have 
proceeded 
for 
a 
fresh 
examination 
for 
the 
mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance in this regard is placed on the orders of the 
Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Vans Inc. USA v. 
Fateh Chand Bhansali and Anr., 2020 SCC OnLine IPAB 44 and 
Prajapati Constructions Ltd. v.  Manoj Ramanand Prajapati and 
Anr., 2018 SCC OnLine IPAB 313. 
CASE SET UP BY THE RESPONDENT 
3. 
The case set up by the respondent no.1 is as under:

nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the respondent, Rajesh Kumar Taneja, has a registered trademark "CLARIWASH" and has filed a suit for infringement against the petitioner, L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. The Trademark Registry had initially issued a certificate for "CHARIWASH" due to a clerical error, but it was rectified and a fresh certificate was issued for "CLARIWASH". The petitioner claims to have adopted the mark "CLARIWASH" in 2010, but has not provided any supporting evidence. The court notes that the petitioner's use of the mark "CLARIWASH" was only in 2013, as per the invoices filed. The petitioner cannot claim monopoly on the "Clari" part of the trademark, as they have various other registered marks. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, 2023:DHC:2089, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 4 of 10 
 
3.1. The respondent no.1 has filed a suit for infringement of the registered 
trademark “CLARIWASH” of the respondent no.1 against the 
petitioner, which is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari. 
3.2. Even though the Examination Report was in respect of the mark 
“CHARIWASH”, the Trademark Journal correctly published the 
mark “CLARIWASH” and not “CHARIWASH”. In May, 2012, the 
Trademark Registry erroneously issued Trademark Registration 
Certificate for the word mark “CHARIWASH”. The respondent no.1 
immediately filed an application to rectify the said clerical error and 
accordingly, the Trademark Registry rectified the error and issued a 
fresh Trademark Registration Certificate for the correct word mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance is placed on the judgment of a Coordinate 
Bench in Epsilon Publishing House Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India and 
Ors., 2009 SCC OnLine Del 3922.  
3.3. Though the petitioner claims adoption of the mark “CLARIWASH” 
in the year 2010, nothing has been filed in support of the same. 
Further, the petitioner has not filed any application for registration of 
the mark “CLARIWASH” till date. 
3.4. Use of the mark “CLARIWASH” by the petitioner or its predecessor 
was only in the year 2013. Attention of the Court in this regard is 
drawn to the invoices filed on behalf petitioner. 
3.5. The petitioner uses several other marks other than the “Clari” 
formative marks. Therefore, it cannot be said that “Clari” belongs to a 
family of marks. 
3.6. The petitioner cannot claim any monopoly on a part of the trademark 
“Clari”. The fact that the petitioner has various marks registered with 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the court analyzed the trademark registration of "CLARIWASH" in favor of the respondent. The petitioner, L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd., was aware of the respondent's use of the trademark but did not apply for registration. The Trademarks Registry issued a registration certificate with an error, showing "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH", but this was later rectified. The correct mark "CLARIWASH" was published in the Trademark Journal No.1519 on January 16, 2012, allowing the petitioner to oppose the application, which they failed to do. The case, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022, was heard by the Delhi High Court, with judgment reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. (Source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, 2023:DHC:2089)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 5 of 10 
 
the prefix “Clari” does not mean that the registration granted in favour 
of the respondent no.1 for the mark “CLARIWASH” is defective. 
There are a number of trademarks registered where the word “Clari” 
has been used as a prefix or suffix.  
3.7. The petitioner was aware of the respondent‟s use of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH”, yet never applied for its trademark registration. 
4. 
Despite opportunity being granted, the respondent no.2 has not filed 
any reply/counter statement or written submissions in the present petition. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
5. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
6. 
In the present case, it appears from the record that the Trademarks 
Registry erroneously issued the Examination Report for the mark 
“CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Yet again, the Registry issued 
a Trademark Registration Certificate in favour of the respondent, wherein 
the mark of the respondent was wrongly shown as “CHARIWASH”. 
Immediately thereafter, an application was filed on behalf of the respondents 
on 14th June, 2012, requesting for rectification of the clerical error and the 
same was allowed by the Registry and a correct Trademark Registration 
Certificate was issued in favour of the respondent for the mark 
“CLARIWASH”. However, it is pertinent to note that the mark of the 
respondent no.1 was published correctly as “CLARIWASH” in the 
Trademark Journal No.1519 on 16th January, 2012.  Therefore, it was open 
for the petitioner or its predecessor to oppose the said application, which 
they failed to do. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", a legal case was heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, with judgment reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. The case, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022, involves Loreal India Pvt. Ltd. as the petitioner and Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care as the respondent.

The legal arguments centered on the registration of a trademark, with the petitioner contesting the respondent's registration due to alleged errors in the examination report by the Registrar. However, the court ruled that the respondent cannot be faulted for the Registrar's mistake, as they did not misrepresent or mislead the Trademark Registry.

The court cited a previous case, Epsilon Publishing, where a Coordinate Bench of the High Court held that a respondent cannot be penalized for the Registrar's failure to follow statutory timelines. The court observed that the respondent has valuable rights to their trademark registration and should not be deprived of these rights due to the Registrar's error.

The petitioner's counsel relied on interim orders from the IPAB in Prajapati Constructions and Vans Inc. USA, but the court noted that these orders are not relevant to the present case, which is at the stage of final hearing. Ultimately, the court decided in favor of the respondent, citing the dicta of the Epsilon Publishing judgment. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, pages 6-7 of 10)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the court ruled that the respondent (Rajesh Kumar Taneja) cannot be faulted for a faulty examination report issued by the Registrar. The registration of a trademark entails valuable rights and the respondent cannot be deprived of these rights due to a mistake by the Registry. The court cited a previous case, Epsilon Publishing, where a Coordinate Bench held that a respondent cannot be penalized for the Registrar's failure to adhere to statutory timelines. The court observed that the respondent cannot be deprived of its rights due to the fault of the Registrar. (Source: 2023:DHC:2089, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 6 of 10 
 
7. 
If the Registrar has committed an error and issued a faulty 
examination report, the respondent no.1 cannot be faulted for the same.  It is 
not that the respondent no.1 had misrepresented or misled the trademark 
Registry into issuing a faulty examination report.  The registration of a 
trademark entails valuable rights and the respondent no.1 cannot be deprived 
of the same on account of mistake committed by the Registry. Therefore, 
this by itself cannot be the ground for removal of the registration granted in 
favour of the respondent no.1. 
8. 
In Epsilon Publishing (supra), a Coordinate Bench of this Court was 
seized of a petition challenging the order of the Registrar renewing the 
trademark granted in favour of the respondent therein.  The ground taken by 
the petitioner was that since the respondent had not filed an application for 
renewal of the registration before its expiration and not paid the surcharge, 
the Registrar was required to remove the trademark from the Register.  
While noting that the Trade Marks Registry has not adhered to the statutory 
timelines, it was held that the respondent cannot be penalized for the same 
and would be entitled to pursue its renewal application.  In the said case, the 
Registrar had admitted that the renewal application filed on behalf of the 
private respondent was not examined and therefore, could not be processed 
further.  It was observed that the private respondent could not be deprived of 
its rights on account of the fault of the Registrar. The relevant observations 
of the court as set out in paragraph 26 are reproduced below: 
“26. 
There may be merit in the contention that the Registrar 
has to follow the procedure as prescribed; however, the essential 
question is not whether the Registrar has any discretion in the 
matter, but, what are the consequences of the Registrar not 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the Trademark Registry did not follow established procedures, resulting in delays. The respondent, Rajesh Kumar Taneja, had filed for trademark renewal within the six-month period, but the application was not processed correctly. The Registrar failed to advertise the removal of the trademark as required under section 25(4) of the Act. The court noted that the respondent cannot be penalized for the Registry's errors and is entitled to pursue their application. The case, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022, was heard in the High Court of Delhi, with judgment reserved on February 27, 2023, and delivered on March 23, 2023. The petitioner, L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd., was represented by Mr. S.K. Bansal and Mr. Ajay Amitabh Suman. (Source: PDF "3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", 2023:DHC:2089)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 7 of 10 
 
following the established procedure? Plainly, in the facts of the 
present case, it is apparent that the Trademark Registry has not 
adhered to the timelines as required. Surely, respondent no.3 
cannot be penalised for the same and would be entitled to purse its 
application for renewal of its trademark. The same was filed well 
within the period of six months and even though the same was not 
accompanied by a fee of surcharge, nonetheless, respondent no.3 
had the right to know the fate of its application. Since no 
deficiency was pointed out at the material time, respondent no.3 
cannot be deprived of its valuable rights to cure the defects within 
the prescribed period. The Registrar also did not advertise the 
removal of the trademark as required under section 25(4) of the 
Act read with Rule 66 of the 2002 Rules. Such advertisement 
would have provided another opportunity for the petitioner to seek 
restoration of the trademark.” 
9. 
The dicta of the aforesaid judgment is squarely applicable to the 
present case. The respondent no.1 cannot be deprived of his valuable rights 
of registration on account of the error of the Registry. 
10. 
Counsel for the petitioner has relied upon the orders passed by the 
IPAB in Prajapati Constructions (supra) and Vans Inc. USA (supra) in 
support of his submission that the Registrar of Trade Marks has to follow 
the statutory procedure prescribed under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 in 
respect of examination of a trade mark application. At the outset, it may be 
noted that both are interim orders passed by the IPAB and therefore, no 
reliance can be placed on the same in the present case, which is at the stage 
of final hearing. After noticing the various procedural lapses committed by 
the Trademark Registry, the IPAB only ordered that the respondent therein 
shall not rely upon the impugned registration in any proceedings during the 
pendency of the rectification proceedings.  There was no order for removal 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the court considered the case of LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE. The petitioner relied on an IPAB order in Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain, but the court found it not applicable. The petitioner's counsel requested the matter be remanded back to the Registry, but the court declined, citing the respondent's registration date of 2012. The court then considered whether the respondent's "CLARIWASH" mark registration was erroneous, given the petitioner's predecessor's "CLARI-FI" mark registration in 2013. The petitioner acquired rights to "CLARI-FI" in 2013. The court judgment was delivered on March 23, 2023 (Source: 2023:DHC:2089, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022).
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 8 of 10 
 
of the registration granted in favour of the respondent on account of lapses 
committed by the Registry.  
11. 
Reliance has also been placed on the order passed by the IPAB in 
Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain (Proporietor) & 
Anr., 2018 (76) PTC 479 [IPAB]. In the aforesaid order, the marks of the 
petitioner and the respondent were identical, namely, “HOWRAH BIDI”. 
The respondent therein had merely added a number to the mark “HOWRAH 
BIDI”, which is not the position in the present case. Therefore, the said 
judgment does not further the case of the petitioner. 
12. 
Counsel for the petitioner also submitted that the matter be remanded 
back to the Registry for reconsideration of the trademark application of the 
respondent no.1 from the stage of issuance of examination report. I am not 
inclined to remand back the matter as this would amount to cancellation of 
the registration already granted in favour of the respondent no.1 as far back 
as in 2012. Therefore, I proceed to consider the matter on merits, i.e., 
whether the registration in favour of the respondent no.1 was granted 
erroneously. 
13. 
At the time when the respondent no.1 filed its application for 
registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” in 2010, there was one mark of the 
predecessor of the petitioner, “CLARI-FI”, that was registered in Class 03. 
All other marks of the petitioner with the term “Clari” have been registered 
subsequent to the registration of the respondent no.1. The petitioner acquired 
rights in the mark “CLARI-FI” in 2013, pursuant to the Asset Transfer 
Agreement dated 19th September, 2013. It is submitted on behalf of the 
petitioner that since the mark of the respondent no.1, “CLARIWASH” was 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi delivered a judgment on March 23, 2023, in the case of LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE. The court dismissed the petition filed by LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD, seeking cancellation of the trademark "CLARIWASH" registered in favor of the respondent.

The petitioner argued that the mark "CLARIWASH" was similar to their earlier registered trademark "CLARI-FI" and could cause confusion among the public. However, the court held that there was no similarity between the two marks, and the petitioner could not seek cancellation of the trademark "CLARIWASH" based on their earlier registration.

The court also noted that the petitioner had taken over approximately 170 marks from Cheryl's Consmeceuticals, but only 12 of these marks used the term "Clari" as part of the mark. The court found that the petitioner could not claim a "family of marks" with the term "Clari" as part of the marks.

The respondent's first use of the mark "CLARIWASH" was shown to be November 16, 2009, while the petitioner's first use of the mark was after this date. The court held that the petitioner had not provided sufficient evidence to show prior adoption or use of the mark "CLARIWASH". The petition was dismissed with no order as to costs. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, 2023:DHC:2089, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary: According to page 9 of the PDF "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf" (2023:DHC:2089, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022), the court ruled that there is no similarity between the marks "CLARI-FI" and "CLARIWASH" to cause confusion. The petitioner, LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD, cannot seek cancellation of the trademark "CLARIWASH" registered in favor of the respondent. The court noted that only 12 out of 170 marks taken over by the petitioner use "Clari" as part of the mark, which is not enough to establish a "family of marks." The judgment was delivered on March 23, 2023. The petitioner was represented by Mr. S.K. Bansal and Mr. Ajay Amitabh Suman, Advocates. (Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 9 of 10 
 
similar to the earlier registered trademark “CLARI-FI”, in respect of similar 
goods, the respondent no.1 should not have been granted registration in 
terms of Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. In my considered view, 
there is no similarity in the marks “CLARI-FI” and “CLARIWASH” so as 
to cause a likelihood of confusion in the public or likelihood of association 
of “CLARIWASH” with “CLARI-FI”. It is a settled position of law that 
while comparing the marks, the marks have to be seen as a whole and 
cannot be broken into their individual components. Reference in this regard 
may be made to the judgment of the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd., AIR 1960 SC 142. 
Therefore, “CLARIWASH” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “WASH” and 
similarly, “CLARI-FI” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “FI”. Taken as a 
whole, there is no similarity in the competing marks so as to cause 
confusion.  Therefore, on the basis of registration of the mark “CLARI-FI”, 
the petitioner cannot seek cancellation of the trademark “CLARIWASH” 
registered in favour of the respondent no.1 in Class 03.  
14. 
Under the Asset Transfer Agreement dated 19th September, 2013, the 
petitioner took over approximately 170 marks, both registered and pending 
registration, from Cheryl‟s Consmeceuticals. Only 12 out of the 170 marks 
use “Clari” as a part of the mark. Therefore, the petitioner cannot say that 
there was a family of marks with the term “Clari” as part of the marks that 
were registered in favour of the petitioner. 
15. 
Counsel for the petitioner has contended that even though the user 
shown in the application filed by the respondent no.1 is 16th November, 
2009, the first invoice placed on record is of 12th May, 2010. In my view, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary: According to page 10 of the PDF "3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf", the court ruled in favor of the respondent, Rajesh Kumar Taneja, in the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022. The petitioner, L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd., failed to prove prior use of the trademark "CLARIWASH". The court noted that the first invoice for "CLARIWASH" was dated December 5, 2013, and sales figures were only provided from 2014. The petitioner had not filed an application for registration of the mark "CLARIWASH" until the date of the judgment. The court dismissed the petition with no order as to costs, citing no grounds for rectification. The judgment was delivered on March 23, 2023, by Judge Amit Bansal. (Source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, page 10)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 10 of 10 
 
this would not make any difference as registration can be granted on a 
„proposed to be used‟ basis. Even if the first user of the respondent no.1 is 
taken to be 12th May, 2010, the user of the petitioner or its predecessor of 
the trademark “CLARIWASH” is after the said date. Nothing has been 
placed on record on behalf of the petitioner to show that the mark 
“CLARIWASH” was adopted in 2010 either by the petitioner or its 
predecessor. It was only on 22nd August, 2013 that a license was issued by 
the FDA, Maharashtra in favour of the predecessor of the petitioner, 
Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals. Even the first invoice placed on record by the 
petitioner that corresponds to the use of “CLARIWASH” is dated 5th 
December, 2013 and the sales figures in the petition have been given only 
from the year 2014. It is also relevant to note that the petitioner has not filed 
any application for registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” till date.   
16. 
In light of the discussion above, no grounds for rectification are made 
out.   
17. 
The petition is dismissed with no order as to costs. 
 
 
                       AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 23, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
